title: Far West Community Associates: Caravans of Gold, Fragments in Time
hero_caption: Henry Spencer Moore. Large Interior Form, 1953/54. Gift of Henry Moore. © 2018 Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York / DACS, London.
description:
The Block Museum, at the heart of Northwestern's Art Circle, in a dynamic, imaginative, and innovative teaching and learning resource for Northwestern and its surrounding communities, featuring a global exhibition program that crosses time periods and cultures and serves as a springboard for thought-provoking discussions relevant to our lives today.

Join us as Northwestern student docents guide us through their current gallery exhibition Caravans of Gold, Fragments in Time: Art, Culture, and Exchange Across Medieval Saharan Africa, which addresses the shared history of West Africa, the Middle East, North Africa and Europe during the critical epoch of the 8th through 16th centuries, when West African gold fueled a global economy and was the impetus for the movement of things, people and ideas across the Sahara Desert to Europe, the Middle East, and beyond. Because of the scarcity of surviving intact works from before the 16th century, the early history and material culture of Africa have rarely been the focus of major exhibitions.

If weather permits, you may also take a walking tour of The Block's Campus Art Walk which spotlights a small selection of their sculptures in the immediate vicinity of the building. Following a wonderful lunch at the beautiful Canterbury Room of the Michigan Shores Country Club, we will return to Northwestern's campus to visit the Alice Millar Chapel, a contemporary Gothic building style that blends the traditional with modern design at its outward appearance. The interior of the building is considered modern with its undulating side walls and breathtaking stained glass windows.

Both the museum and chapel have limited capacity and the gallery exhibition contains very rare, precious objects, so our morning and afternoon tours will alternate to allow a limited number of people in the areas at one time.
